unit_learning_outcomes.description: Define the concepts of motor skill and motor learning and describe the stages of motor skill acquisition
Reflect on the development, implementation and evaluation of a motor skill training program and make recommendations to improve future training programs and outcomes.
Design an evidence-based motor skill training program which is specifically tailored to a healthy person’s goals and current ability level
Analyse and classify motor skills according to the relevant anatomical, biomechanical, environmental, physiological and psychological requirements
Critically evaluate a motor skill training program
Describe strategies to optimise motor learning and performance in healthy people
Implement, and progress an evidence-based motor skill training program in healthy people

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: General prep for class (including online activities) and revising of content
General prep for class and revising of content

enrolment_rules.description: 120cp at 1000 level or above including ((HLTH108 or ANAT1001) and ((HLTH109 or ANAT1002) or (MEDI203 or MEDI2100)) and (PHTY302 or PHTY3001))

assessments.description: Training and testing program overview and justification of training and testing
Group presentation focussed on implementation and results of the training program as well as reflection on development, implementation and evaluation of the program.
Skill analysis of assigned motor task

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances, North Ryde
data.subject_search_title: PHTY3002 - Human Motor Learning and Performance

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit provides you with a broad overview of motor learning, performance, and skill acquisition as it relates to humans. The unit integrates your prior study of anatomy, biomechanics, physiology, neuroscience, behavioural sciences, and psychology as it pertains to human movement. The unit explores the classification of motor skills, the neuromotor processes that underpin motor performance, and features of the learning environment that can be manipulated to promote motor learning in a coaching and/or rehabilitation context. The aim of the unit is to provide a behavioural and physiological understanding of the acquisition and execution of skilled motor actions and how to train and/or retrain motor actions.  You will apply your learning through a group project in which you train a healthy person to learn or improve a motor skill. Through this unit you will learn how to instruct and provide feedback as appropriate for a potential future career as a practitioner/clinician.
data.search_title: PHTY3002 - Human Motor Learning and Performance
